trans-unit.source: NAMD with Microsoft HPC Pack on Linux VMs | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: NAMD with Microsoft HPC Pack on Linux VMs | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Deploy a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster on Azure and run a NAMD simulation with charmrun on multiple Linux compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: Deploy a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster on Azure and run a NAMD simulation with charmrun on multiple Linux compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Run NAMD with Microsoft HPC Pack on Linux compute nodes in Azure
trans-unit.target: Run NAMD with Microsoft HPC Pack on Linux compute nodes in Azure

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to deploy a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster on Azure and run a NAMD job with charmrun on multiple Linux compute nodes in a virtual cluster network to calculate and visualize the structure of a large biomolecular system.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to deploy a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster on Azure and run a NAMD job with charmrun on multiple Linux compute nodes in a virtual cluster network to calculate and visualize the structure of a large biomolecular system.

trans-unit.source: NAMD (for Nanoscale Molecular Dynamics program) is a parallel molecular dynamics package designed for high-performance simulation of large biomolecular systems containing up to millions of atoms, such as viruses, cell structures, and large proteins.
trans-unit.target: NAMD (for Nanoscale Molecular Dynamics program) is a parallel molecular dynamics package designed for high-performance simulation of large biomolecular systems containing up to millions of atoms, such as viruses, cell structures, and large proteins.

trans-unit.source: NAMD scales to hundreds of cores for typical simulations and to more than 500,000 cores for the largest simulations.
trans-unit.target: NAMD scales to hundreds of cores for typical simulations and to more than 500,000 cores for the largest simulations.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft HPC Pack provides features to run a variety of large-scale HPC and parallel applications, including MPI applications, on clusters of Microsoft Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft HPC Pack provides features to run a variety of large-scale HPC and parallel applications, including MPI applications, on clusters of Microsoft Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Starting in Microsoft HPC Pack 2012 R2, HPC Pack also supports running Linux HPC applications on Linux compute node VMs deployed in an HPC Pack cluster.
trans-unit.target: Starting in Microsoft HPC Pack 2012 R2, HPC Pack also supports running Linux HPC applications on Linux compute node VMs deployed in an HPC Pack cluster.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for an introduction to using Linux compute nodes with HPC Pack.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for an introduction to using Linux compute nodes with HPC Pack.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes - See Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure for the prerequisites and steps to deploy an HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes on Azure by using an Azure PowerShell script and HPC Pack images in the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes - See Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure for the prerequisites and steps to deploy an HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes on Azure by using an Azure PowerShell script and HPC Pack images in the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: Following is a sample XML configuration file you can use with the script to deploy an Azure-based HPC Pack cluster consisting of a Windows Server 2012 R2 head node and 4 size Large (A3) CentOS 6.6 compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: Following is a sample XML configuration file you can use with the script to deploy an Azure-based HPC Pack cluster consisting of a Windows Server 2012 R2 head node and 4 size Large (A3) CentOS 6.6 compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Substitute appropriate values for your subscription and service names.
trans-unit.target: Substitute appropriate values for your subscription and service names.

trans-unit.target: <html></html>Subscription-1<html></html>

trans-unit.target: <html></html>MyVNet<html></html>

trans-unit.target: <html></html>Subnet-1<html></html>

trans-unit.target: <html></html>HeadNodeAsDC<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Change directory to the ~/.ssh directory.
trans-unit.target: Change directory to the ~/.ssh directory.

trans-unit.source: The private key is stored in id_rsa and the public key in id_rsa.pub.
trans-unit.target: The private key is stored in id_rsa and the public key in id_rsa.pub.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Private and public keys</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Private and public keys</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add the key pair to the HPC Pack cluster
trans-unit.target: Add the key pair to the HPC Pack cluster

trans-unit.source: Make a Remote Desktop connnection to your head node with your HPC Pack administrator account (the administrator account you set up when you ran the deployment script).
trans-unit.target: Make a Remote Desktop connnection to your head node with your HPC Pack administrator account (the administrator account you set up when you ran the deployment script).

trans-unit.source: Use standard Windows Server procedures to create a domain user account in the cluster's Active Directory domain.
trans-unit.target: Use standard Windows Server procedures to create a domain user account in the cluster's Active Directory domain.

trans-unit.source: For example, use the Active Directory User and Computers tool on the head node.
trans-unit.target: For example, use the Active Directory User and Computers tool on the head node.

trans-unit.source: The examples in this article assume you create a domain user named hpclab\hpcuser.
trans-unit.target: The examples in this article assume you create a domain user named hpclab\hpcuser.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named C:\cred.xml and copy the RSA key data into it.
trans-unit.target: Create a file named C:\cred.xml and copy the RSA key data into it.

trans-unit.source: You can find an example of this file in the Appendix at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: You can find an example of this file in the Appendix at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Open a Command window and enter the following command to set the credentials data for the hpclab\hpcuser account.
trans-unit.target: Open a Command window and enter the following command to set the credentials data for the hpclab\hpcuser account.

trans-unit.source: You use the extendeddata parameter to pass the name of C:\cred.xml file you created for the key data.
trans-unit.target: You use the extendeddata parameter to pass the name of C:\cred.xml file you created for the key data.

trans-unit.source: This command completes successfully without output.
trans-unit.target: This command completes successfully without output.

trans-unit.source: After setting the credentials for the user accounts you need to run jobs, store the cred.xml file in a secure location, or delete it.
trans-unit.target: After setting the credentials for the user accounts you need to run jobs, store the cred.xml file in a secure location, or delete it.

trans-unit.source: If you generated the RSA key pair on one of your Linux nodes, remember to delete the keys after you finish using them.
trans-unit.target: If you generated the RSA key pair on one of your Linux nodes, remember to delete the keys after you finish using them.

trans-unit.source: HPC Pack does not set up mutual trust if it finds an existing id_rsa file or id_rsa.pub file.
trans-unit.target: HPC Pack does not set up mutual trust if it finds an existing id_rsa file or id_rsa.pub file.

trans-unit.source: We don’t recommend running a Linux job as a cluster administrator on a shared cluster, because a job submitted by an administrator runs under the root account on the Linux nodes.
trans-unit.target: We don’t recommend running a Linux job as a cluster administrator on a shared cluster, because a job submitted by an administrator runs under the root account on the Linux nodes.

trans-unit.source: A job submitted by a non-administrator user runs under a local Linux user account with the same name as the job user, and HPC Pack sets up mutual trust for this Linux user across all the nodes allocated to the job.
trans-unit.target: A job submitted by a non-administrator user runs under a local Linux user account with the same name as the job user, and HPC Pack sets up mutual trust for this Linux user across all the nodes allocated to the job.

trans-unit.source: You can set up the Linux user manually on the Linux nodes before running the job, or HPC Pack creates the user automatically when the job is submitted.
trans-unit.target: You can set up the Linux user manually on the Linux nodes before running the job, or HPC Pack creates the user automatically when the job is submitted.

trans-unit.source: If HPC Pack creates the user, HPC Pack deletes it after the job completes.
trans-unit.target: If HPC Pack creates the user, HPC Pack deletes it after the job completes.

trans-unit.source: The keys are removed after job completion on the nodes to reduce security threats.
trans-unit.target: The keys are removed after job completion on the nodes to reduce security threats.

trans-unit.source: Set up a file share for Linux nodes
trans-unit.target: Set up a file share for Linux nodes

trans-unit.source: Now set up a standard SMB share on a folder on the head node, and mount the shared folder on all Linux nodes to allow the Linux nodes to access NAMD files with a common path.
trans-unit.target: Now set up a standard SMB share on a folder on the head node, and mount the shared folder on all Linux nodes to allow the Linux nodes to access NAMD files with a common path.

trans-unit.source: See the file sharing options and steps in <link><linkText>Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack Cluster in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See the file sharing options and steps in <link><linkText>Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack Cluster in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: (We recommend mounting a shared folder on the head node in this article because CentOS 6.6 Linux nodes don’t currently support the Azure File service, which provides similar features.
trans-unit.target: (We recommend mounting a shared folder on the head node in this article because CentOS 6.6 Linux nodes don’t currently support the Azure File service, which provides similar features.

trans-unit.source: For more about mounting an Azure File share, see <link><linkText>Persisting connections to Microsoft Azure Files</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more about mounting an Azure File share, see <link><linkText>Persisting connections to Microsoft Azure Files</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Create a folder on the head node, and share it to everyone by setting Read/Write privileges.
trans-unit.target: Create a folder on the head node, and share it to everyone by setting Read/Write privileges.

trans-unit.source: In this example, \\\\CentOS66HN\Namd is the name of the folder, where CentOS66HN is the host name of the head node.
trans-unit.target: In this example, \\\\CentOS66HN\Namd is the name of the folder, where CentOS66HN is the host name of the head node.

trans-unit.source: Extract the NAMD files in the folder by using a Windows version of tar or another Windows utility that operates on .tar archives.
trans-unit.target: Extract the NAMD files in the folder by using a Windows version of tar or another Windows utility that operates on .tar archives.

trans-unit.source:
Extract the NAMD tar archive to \\CentOS66HN\Namd
amd2, and extract the tutorial files under \\CentOS66HN\Namd
amd2
amdsample.
trans-unit.target:
Extract the NAMD tar archive to \\CentOS66HN\Namd
amd2, and extract the tutorial files under \\CentOS66HN\Namd
amd2
amdsample.

trans-unit.source: Open a Windows PowerShell window and run the following commands to mount the shared folder.
trans-unit.target: Open a Windows PowerShell window and run the following commands to mount the shared folder.

trans-unit.source: The first command creates a folder named /namd2 on all nodes in the LinuxNodes group.
trans-unit.target: The first command creates a folder named /namd2 on all nodes in the LinuxNodes group.

trans-unit.source: The second command mounts the shared folder //CentOS66HN/Namd/namd2 onto the folder with dir_mode and file_mode bits set to 777.
trans-unit.target: The second command mounts the shared folder //CentOS66HN/Namd/namd2 onto the folder with dir_mode and file_mode bits set to 777.

trans-unit.source: The username and password in the command should be the credentials of a user on the head node.
trans-unit.target: The username and password in the command should be the credentials of a user on the head node.

trans-unit.source: The “\`” symbol in the second command is an escape symbol for PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The “\`” symbol in the second command is an escape symbol for PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: “\`,” means the “,” (comma character) is a part of the command.
trans-unit.target: “\`,” means the “,” (comma character) is a part of the command.

trans-unit.source: Prepare to run a NAMD job
trans-unit.target: Prepare to run a NAMD job

trans-unit.source: Your NAMD job needs a nodelist file for charmrun to know the number of nodes to use when starting NAMD processes.
trans-unit.target: Your NAMD job needs a nodelist file for charmrun to know the number of nodes to use when starting NAMD processes.

trans-unit.source: You'll write a Bash script that generates the nodelist file and runs charmrun with this nodelist file.
trans-unit.target: You'll write a Bash script that generates the nodelist file and runs charmrun with this nodelist file.

trans-unit.source: You can then submit a NAMD job in HPC Cluster Manager that calls this script.
trans-unit.target: You can then submit a NAMD job in HPC Cluster Manager that calls this script.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables and nodelist file
trans-unit.target: Environment variables and nodelist file

trans-unit.source: Information about nodes and cores is in the $CCP_NODES_CORES environment variable, which is automatically set by the HPC Pack head node when the job is activated.
trans-unit.target: Information about nodes and cores is in the $CCP_NODES_CORES environment variable, which is automatically set by the HPC Pack head node when the job is activated.

trans-unit.source: The format for the $CCP_NODES_CORES variable is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The format for the $CCP_NODES_CORES variable is as follows:

trans-unit.source: This lists the total number of nodes, node names, and number of cores on each node that are allocated to the job.
trans-unit.target: This lists the total number of nodes, node names, and number of cores on each node that are allocated to the job.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the job needs 10 cores to run, the value of $CCP_NODES_CORES will be similar to:
trans-unit.target: For example, if the job needs 10 cores to run, the value of $CCP_NODES_CORES will be similar to:

trans-unit.source: Following is the information in the nodelist file, which the script will generate:
trans-unit.target: Following is the information in the nodelist file, which the script will generate:

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Bash script to create a nodelist file
trans-unit.target: Bash script to create a nodelist file

trans-unit.source: Using a text editor of your choice, create the following Bash script in the folder containing the NAMD program files and name it hpccharmrun.sh.
trans-unit.target: Using a text editor of your choice, create the following Bash script in the folder containing the NAMD program files and name it hpccharmrun.sh.

trans-unit.source: A complete sample of this file is in the Appendix of this article.
trans-unit.target: A complete sample of this file is in the Appendix of this article.

trans-unit.source: This bash script does the following things.
trans-unit.target: This bash script does the following things.

trans-unit.source: Save your script as a text file with Linux line endings (LF only, not CR LF).
trans-unit.target: Save your script as a text file with Linux line endings (LF only, not CR LF).

trans-unit.source: This ensures that it runs properly on the Linux nodes.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that it runs properly on the Linux nodes.

trans-unit.source: Define some variables.
trans-unit.target: Define some variables.

trans-unit.source: Get node information from the environment variables.
trans-unit.target: Get node information from the environment variables.

trans-unit.source: $NODESCORES stores a list of split words from $CCP_NODES_CORES.
trans-unit.target: $NODESCORES stores a list of split words from $CCP_NODES_CORES.

trans-unit.source: $COUNT is the size of $NODESCORES.
trans-unit.target: $COUNT is the size of $NODESCORES.

trans-unit.source: If the $CCP_NODES_CORES variable is not set, just start charmrun directly.
trans-unit.target: If the $CCP_NODES_CORES variable is not set, just start charmrun directly.

trans-unit.source: (This should only occur when you run this script directly on your Linux nodes.)
trans-unit.target: (This should only occur when you run this script directly on your Linux nodes.)

trans-unit.source: Or create a nodelist file for charmrun.
trans-unit.target: Or create a nodelist file for charmrun.

trans-unit.source: else
trans-unit.target: else

trans-unit.source: # Create the nodelist file
trans-unit.target: # Create the nodelist file

trans-unit.source: NODELIST_PATH=${SCRIPT_PATH}/nodelist_$$
trans-unit.target: NODELIST_PATH=${SCRIPT_PATH}/nodelist_$$

trans-unit.source: Exit with the charmrun return status.
trans-unit.target: Exit with the charmrun return status.

trans-unit.source: Submit a NAMD job
trans-unit.target: Submit a NAMD job

trans-unit.source: Now you are ready to submit a NAMD job in HPC Cluster Manager.
trans-unit.target: Now you are ready to submit a NAMD job in HPC Cluster Manager.

trans-unit.source: Connect to your cluster head node and start HPC Cluster Manager.
trans-unit.target: Connect to your cluster head node and start HPC Cluster Manager.

trans-unit.source: In Node Management, ensure that the Linux compute nodes are in the Online state.
trans-unit.target: In Node Management, ensure that the Linux compute nodes are in the Online state.

trans-unit.source: If they are not, select them and click Bring Online.
trans-unit.target: If they are not, select them and click Bring Online.

trans-unit.source: In Job Management, click New Job.
trans-unit.target: In Job Management, click New Job.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for job such as hpccharmrun.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for job such as hpccharmrun.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New HPC job</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New HPC job</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Job Details page, under Job Resources, select the type of resource as Node and set the Minimum to 3.
trans-unit.target: On the Job Details page, under Job Resources, select the type of resource as Node and set the Minimum to 3.

trans-unit.source: In this example we'll run the job on 3 Linux nodes and each node has 4 cores.
trans-unit.target: In this example we'll run the job on 3 Linux nodes and each node has 4 cores.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job resources</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job resources</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Task Details and I/O Redirection page, add a new task to the job and set the following values.
trans-unit.target: On the Task Details and I/O Redirection page, add a new task to the job and set the following values.

trans-unit.source: Command line -
trans-unit.target: Command line -

trans-unit.source: /namd2/hpccharmrun.sh ++remote-shell ssh /namd2/namd2 /namd2/namdsample/1-2-sphere/ubq_ws_eq.conf > /namd2/namd2_hpccharmrun.log
trans-unit.target: /namd2/hpccharmrun.sh ++remote-shell ssh /namd2/namd2 /namd2/namdsample/1-2-sphere/ubq_ws_eq.conf > /namd2/namd2_hpccharmrun.log

trans-unit.source: Working directory - /namd2
trans-unit.target: Working directory - /namd2

trans-unit.source: Minimum - 3
trans-unit.target: Minimum - 3

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Task details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Task details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You set the working directory here because charmrun tries to navigate to the same working directory on each node.
trans-unit.target: You set the working directory here because charmrun tries to navigate to the same working directory on each node.

trans-unit.source: If the working directory isn't set, HPC Pack starts the command in a randomly named folder created on one of the Linux nodes.
trans-unit.target: If the working directory isn't set, HPC Pack starts the command in a randomly named folder created on one of the Linux nodes.

trans-unit.source: This causes the following error on the other nodes:
trans-unit.target: This causes the following error on the other nodes:

trans-unit.source: /bin/bash: line 37: cd: /tmp/nodemanager_task_94_0.mFlQSN: No such file or directory. To avoid this, specify a folder path which can be accessed by all nodes as the working directory.
trans-unit.target: /bin/bash: line 37: cd: /tmp/nodemanager_task_94_0.mFlQSN: No such file or directory. To avoid this, specify a folder path which can be accessed by all nodes as the working directory.

trans-unit.source: Click Submit to run this job.
trans-unit.target: Click Submit to run this job.

trans-unit.source: By default, HPC Pack submits the job as your current logged-on user account.
trans-unit.target: By default, HPC Pack submits the job as your current logged-on user account.

trans-unit.source: A dialog box might prompt you to enter the user name and password after you click Submit.
trans-unit.target: A dialog box might prompt you to enter the user name and password after you click Submit.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job credentials</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job credentials</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Under some conditions HPC Pack remembers the user information you input before and won’t show this dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Under some conditions HPC Pack remembers the user information you input before and won’t show this dialog box.

trans-unit.source: To make HPC Pack show it again, enter the following in a Command window and then submit the job.
trans-unit.target: To make HPC Pack show it again, enter the following in a Command window and then submit the job.

trans-unit.source: The job takes several minutes to finish.
trans-unit.target: The job takes several minutes to finish.

trans-unit.source:
Find the job log at \<html></html>\Namd
amd2
amd2_hpccharmrun.log and the output files in \<html></html>\Namd
amd2
amdsample\1-2-sphere\.
trans-unit.target:
Find the job log at \<html></html>\Namd
amd2
amd2_hpccharmrun.log and the output files in \<html></html>\Namd
amd2
amdsample\1-2-sphere\.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, start VMD to view your job results.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, start VMD to view your job results.

trans-unit.source: The steps for visualizing the NAMD output files (in this case, a ubiquitin protein molecule in a water sphere) are beyond the scope of this article.
trans-unit.target: The steps for visualizing the NAMD output files (in this case, a ubiquitin protein molecule in a water sphere) are beyond the scope of this article.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>NAMD Tutorial</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>NAMD Tutorial</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job results</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job results</linkText>
